metadata.title: Palladium complexes of (benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl)amine ligands as catalysts for methoxycarbonylation of olefins
metadata.journal: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical

Scheme 1 Syntheses of neutral (benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl)amine palladium complexes 1–3. Scheme 2 Syntheses of cationic (benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl)amine palladium complexes 4 and 5. Scheme 3 Methoxycarbonylation of 1-hexene using complexes 1–5 as catalysts. Scheme 4 Proposed hydride (A) and carbomethoxy (B) methoxycarbonylation mechanisms using palladium complexes. Fig. 1 Thermal ellipsoid plot (50% probability) of 5a illustrating the square planar coordination geometry of the Pd(II) ion. Hydrogen atoms and the BAr4 anion have been omitted for clarity. Selected bond lenghths [Å] and angles [°] for 5a: Pd(1)C(1) 2.069 (2), Pd(1)N(3) 2.1290(19), Pd(1)P(1) 2.3003(8), Pd(11)P(2) 2.3311(8), C(1)Pd(1)N(3) 178.97(9), C(1)Pd(1)P(2) 87.54(7), N(3)Pd(1)P(1) 94.19(5). Fig. 2 Graph of percentage conversion and regioselectivity using complex 4 showing the influence of time on the methoxycarbonylation reactions. Solvent: toluene 40mL and methanol 30mL; [Pd]:[1-hexene] ratio 200:1, Pd:HCl ratio; 1:10; P (CO)=60bar; temperature: 90°C. Fig. 3 The effect of substrate on percentage conversion and regioselectivity towards branched product using catalyst 4, solvent: toluene (40mL) and methanol (30mL); [substrate]:[Pd] ratio 200:1, [Pd/]:HCl ratio; 1:10; P (CO)=60bar; temperature: 90°C; time 24h. Palladium complexes of (benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl)amine ligands as catalysts for methoxycarbonylation of olefins Thandeka A. Tshabalala Stephen O. Ojwach ⁎ Matthew A. Akerman School of Chemistry and Physics, Pietermaritzburg Campus, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Private Bag X01, Scottsville 3209, South Africa School of Chemistry and Physics Pietermaritzburg Campus University of KwaZulu-Natal Private Bag X01 Scottsville 3209 South Africa ⁎ Corresponding author. Fax: +27 33 260 5009. Graphical abstract Reactions of N-(1H-benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl)-2-methoxy aniline (L1) and N-(1H-benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl)-2-bromo aniline (L2) with either [PdCl2(COD)] or [PdClMe(COD)] afforded the neutral palladium complexes [PdCl2(L1)] (1), [PdClMe(L1)] (2) and [PdClMe(L2] (3), respectively. Treatment of 2 and 3 with one equivalent of PPh3 in the presence of NaBAr4 (Ar=3,5-(CF3)2C6H3) produced the corresponding cationic species, [PdMe(L1)]BAr4 (4) and [PdMe(L2)]BAr4 (5). All the palladium complexes formed active catalysts in the methoxycarbonylation of alkenes to produce linear and branched esters. The catalytic behaviour was dependent on the catalyst structure, presence of PPh3, acid promoter and alkene chain length. Keywords Methoxycarbonylation Alkenes Palladium catalysts Regioselectivity 1 Introduction The methoxycarbonylation reaction has become one of the most valuable organic reactions in the functionalization of olefins to produce a wide range of industrial and domestic products such as detergents, cosmetics and pharmaceuticals [1–3]. A number of phosphine based transition metal complexes have been applied in methoxycarbonylation reactions over decades [4–9]. To date, palladium-catalysts have attracted much interest in the methoxycarbonylation of olefins due to their superior catalytic activities [10]. Depending on the catalytic system used and reaction conditions employed, high regioselectivity towards branched or linear products can be obtained using Pd(II) catalysts. In recent years, a number of Pd complexes containing varied ligand architectures have been reported to show high activity as well as selectivity for methoxycarbonylation of olefins such as styrene1, 1-hexene [11] or ethene [12] under mild reaction conditions. For instance, under low partial pressures of carbon monoxide and moderate temperatures, some of these catalyst systems show high regioselectivity (>90%) towards branched esters [13–25]. Currently, one such catalyst design that is attracting significant attention are the mixed nitrogen–phosphine donor Pd complexes. This is presumably due to their perceived stability and tolerance to impurities. For example, Pd catalysts of the type [PdCl2(Ph2PNHpy-k2 P,N)] and [PdCl(Ph2PNHpy-k2 P,N)(PPh3)]Cl were reported to be active and stable in the methoxycarbonylation of styrene [11]. In this paper, we report the syntheses of some neutral and cationic Pd(II) complexes anchored on (benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl) amine ligands and their applications as potential catalysts in the methoxycarbonylation of alkenes. The effects of catalyst structure, identity of alkene substrate, reaction conditions, and nature of acid promoter used have been systematically studied and are herein reported. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material and methods All moisture and air sensitive reactions were performed using standard Schlenk line techniques. Methanol, acetone, diethyl ether, dichloromethane, absolute ethanol, ethyl acetate, toluene, DMSO-d6, potassium iodide (KI), sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and potassium hydroxide (KOH) were purchased from Merck. Chloroform (CDCl3), styrene, σ-olefins, p-TsOH, hydrochloric acid (HCl), oxalic acid, sulfuric acid (H2SO4), HBr and PPh3 were obtained from Sigma–Aldrich. The chemicals, 2-chloromethylbenzimidazole, aniline (≥99.5%) 2-methoxyaniline (≥99.5%), 2-aminothiophenol (≥99%), and 2-bromoaniline (98%) were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich and were used without further purification. NaBAr4 (Ar4 =3,5-(CF3)2C6H3) was obtained from Boulder Scientific and used as received. Starting materials [PdCl2(COD)] [26] and [PdClMe(COD)] [27] were synthesized following literature methods. Ligands L1–L2 were prepared following our recently published procedures [28]. Nuclear magnetic resonance spectra were acquired at 400MHz for 1H, 100MHz for 13C and 162MHz for 31P on a Bruker Avance spectrometer equipped with Bruker magnet (9.395 T). All coupling constants are reported in Hertz, Hz. Elemental analyses were carried out using CHNS-O Flash 2000 thermoscientific analyzer. Mass spectral analyses were conducted using micromass LCT premier mass spectrometer. 2.2 Syntheses of palladium complexes 2.2.1 [{N-(1H-benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl)-2-methoxyaniline}PdCl2] (1) To a solution of L1 (0.20g, 0.83mmol) in CH2Cl2 (10mL) was added a solution of [Pd(COD)Cl2] (0.22g, 0.83mmol) in CH2Cl2 (10mL) and the mixture was stirred for 24h to give a yellow precipitate. The crude product was filtered and recrystallized from CH2Cl2- hexane mixture to afford complex 1 as a light yellow solid. Yield=0.27g (77%). 1H NMR (DMSO): δ(ppm): 0.78 (s, 3H, OCH3); 4.90 (s, 2H, CH2); 6.48–6.57 (d, 1H,3 J HH =7.60, Ph); 6.59 (t, 1H, 3 J HH =5.36, Ph,); 6.61(d, 1H, 3 J HH =4.98, Ph,); 6.69 (d, 1H, 3 J HH =6.51, Ph); 6.84 (dd, 2H, 3 J HH =4.80, Bzim); 6.86–7.27 (dd, 2H, 3 J HH =7.66, Bzim). MS (ESI) m/z (%) 254 (M+-Cl2–Pd, 100%). Anal. Calc. for C15H13N3PdCl2.0.75CH2Cl2: C, 38.97; H, 3.06; N, 8.66. Found: C, 39.01; H, 3.66; N, 8.76. 2.2.2 [{N-(1H-benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl)-2methoxyaniline}PdClMe] (2) Complex 2 was synthesized following the procedure described for 1 using L1 (0.10g, 0.41) and PdCl(COD) Me (0.10g,0.35mmol) in Et2O (10mL). Yield=0. 09g (86%) 1H NMR (DMSO-d6): δ(ppm): 0.78 (s, 3H, OCH3); 3.84 (s, 3H, CH3); 4.91 (s, 2H, CH2); 5.17 (s, 2H, Ph); 6.50 (d, 1H, 3 J HH =3.74, Ph); 6.58 (t, 1H, 3 J HH =3.21, Ph); 6.69 (d, 1H, 3 J HH =3.34, Ph); 6.81 (t, 1H, 3 J HH =5.23, Ph); 7.35 (dd, 2H, 3 J HH =6.86, Bzim); 7.51 (dd, 2H, 3 J HH =7.77, Bzim). Anal. Calc. for C16H18N3PdClO: C, 46.85; H, 4.42; N, 10.24. Found: C, 47.11; H, 4.11; N, 8.58. 2.2.3 [{N-(1H-benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl)-2-bromoaniline} [PdClMe] (3) Complex 3 was prepared according to the procedure for 1 using L2 (0.10g, 0.34mmol) and PdCl(COD) Me (0.10g, 0.34mmol). Yield=0.09 (58%) 1H NMR (DMSO-d6): H (ppm): 0.80 (s, 3H, CH3); 4.61 (s, 2H, CH2);5.01 (s, 2H, CH2); 6.27 (d, 1H, 3 J HH =6.67, Ph); 6.56 (t, 1H, 3 J HH =5.64, Ph); 7.06 (t, 1H,3 J HH =6.77, Ph); 7.15 (d, 1H, 3 J HH =7.89, Ph); 7.31 (dd, 2H, 3 J HH =6.78, Bzim); 7.48 (dd, 2H, 3 J HH =7.33, Bzim). MS (ESI) m/z (%) 482 (M+-Cl, 22%). Anal. Calc. for C15H15N3BrPdCl: C, 39.24; H, 3.29; N, 9.15. Found: C, 38.94; H, 3.87; N, 8.99. 2.2.4 [{N-(1H-benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl)-2-methoxyaniline} [PdMe(PPh3)] BAr4 (4) To a suspension of 2 (0.02g, 0.09mmol), in CH2Cl2 (10mL), PPh3 (0.01g, 0.09mmol) and NaBAr4 (Ar4 =3,5-(CF3)2C6H3) (0.037g, 0.09mmol) were added and stirred for 24h. The solution mixture was filtered and the filtrate concentrated to approximately 3mL and recrystallized from hexane/CH2Cl2 solvent mixture to obtain compound 4 as a yellow crystalline solid. Yield=0.08g (66%). 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ (ppm):0.95 (s, 3H, CH3), 3.43 (s, 3H, OCH3), 5.52 (s, 2H, CH2), 6.47 (d, 1H, Ph-aniline), 6.69 (t, 1H, 3 J HH =6.80, Ph), 6.75 (d, 1H, 3 J HH =7.20, Ph), 7.21 (m, 6H, 3 J HH =7.60, PPh3), 7.34 (d, 2H, 3 J HH =6.80, Bzim), 7.36 (d, 8H, 3 J HH =8.00, BAr4), 7.50 (m, 9H, 3 J HH =8.00, PPh3), 7.71 (t, 4H, 3 J HH =7.60, BAr4), 7.72 (d, 2H, 3 J HH =7.88, Bzim). 31P NMR (CDCl3) δ(ppm): 37.85. Anal. Calc. for C66H45BF24ON3PPd: C, 52.46; H,3.05; N, 2.82. Found: C, 52.94; H, 1.39; N, 3.09. 2.2.5 [{N-(1H-benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl)-2-bromoaniline} [PdMe(PPh3)] BAr4 (5) Complex 5 was prepared according to the same procedure for 4 using 3 (0.04g, 0.09mmol), PPh3 (0.02g, 0.09mmol) and NaBAr4 (Ar4 =3,5-(CF3)2C6H3) (0.08g, 0.09mmol). Yield=0.06 (67%). 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ(ppm): 0.98 (s, 3H, CH3), 5.65 (s, 2H, CH2), 6.33 (d, 1H, 3 J HH =6.40, Ph), 6.60 (t, 1H, 3 J HH =6.80, Ph), 7.10 (d, 1H, Ph), 7.20 (t, 1H, 3 J HH =6.40, Ph), 7.25 (m, 6H, PPh3), 7.38 (d, 2H, 3 J HH =6.80, Bzim), 7.40 (8H, 3 J HH =8.40, BAr4), 7.59 (m, 9H, 3 J HH =7.20, PPh3), 7.63 (d, 2H, 3 J HH =7.60, Bzim), 7.74 (4H, 3 J HH =7.60, BAr4) 31P NMR (CDCl3): 30.63. Anal. Calc. for C65H45BBrF24N3PPd:C, 50.30; H, 2.92; N, 2.70. Found: C, 50.61; H, 2.72; N, 2.87. 2.3 General procedure for the methoxycarbonylation reactions The catalytic methoxycarbonylation reactions were performed in a stainless steel autoclave equipped with temperature control unit and a sample valve. In a typical experiment, complex 4 (48.78mg, 0.08mmol), PPh3 (0.04g, 0.16mmol), HCl (0.03mL, 0.80mmol) and 1-hexene (2mL, 15.93mmol) were dissolved in a mixture of methanol (20mL) and toluene (40mL). The reactor was evacuated and the catalytic solution was introduced to the reactor via a cannula. The reactor was purged three times with CO, set at the required pressure and temperature and the reaction stirred at 500rpm. At the end of the reaction time, the reaction was cooled, excess CO was vented off and the samples drawn for GC analysis to determine the percentage conversion of the alkene substrate to esters. GC–MS analyses were run under the following standard chromatography conditions: −25m CPSil 19 capillary column, 1.2mm film thickness, Helium carrier column gas 5psi, injector temperature 250°C, oven program 50°C for 4min rising to 200°C at 20°C/min and holding at 200°C. The branched and linear esters were assigned using standard authentic samples. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Syntheses of neutral and cationic Pd(II) complex synthesis Compounds L1 and L2 were prepared by reaction of 2-(chloromethyl) benzoimidazole with the appropriate aniline derivatives following our reported literature procedure [28]. Reactions of L1 and L2 with either [PdCl2(COD)] or [PdClMe(COD)] produced the corresponding neutral complexes 1–3 in moderate yields (58–86%), Scheme 1 . Subsequent treatment of complexes 1 and 3 with one equivalent of NaBAr4 (Ar4 =3,5-(CF3)2C6H3) in the presence of PPh3 afforded the respective cationic compounds 4 and 5, respectively in high yields (Scheme 2 ). The new compounds were characterized by 1H, 31P NMR spectroscopies, mass spectrometry, elemental analyses and single X-ray crystallography for complex 5. In a typical 1H NMR spectrum, the CH2 linker protons in the ligands were useful in determination of their respective complex formation. For example, the 1H NMR spectra of L1 and its corresponding complex 1 showed CH2 protons signals at 4.65ppm and 4.90ppm, respectively. One interesting observation in the 1H NMR data was the appearance of two broad signals for the CH2 protons at 4.61ppm and 5.01ppm for complex 4 in addition to two sets of aromatic protons. This was indicative of the presence of two isomers, which may arise from unsymmetrical nature of complexes 3 and 4 due to PdMe and PdCl bonds [29]. The cationic complexes 4 and 5 were further characterized by 31P NMR in order to determine the presence and nature of coordination of PPh3 ligand. Complexes 4 and 5 displayed one singlet in their 31P NMR spectra between 37.85ppm and 30.63ppm, respectively (Fig. S1). These values fall within typical 31P NMR signals between 30.70 and 35.70ppm for related mono-coordinated PPh3 compounds and agrees with the proposed structures in Scheme 2 [30–37]. Mass spectrometry was also used to establish the formation and identity of these complexes. The complexes showed typical fragmentation patterns consistent with a loss of a halide group. For instance, complex 3 losses a Cl− ion (m/z =423.96) followed by a loss of PdMeCl fragment to produce a peak at m/z =304 corresponding to L4 (Fig. S2). In order to confirm the proposed coordination modes of ligands L1 and L2 to Pd, attempts were made to grow single crystals suitable for X-ray analyses of the complexes. In one such instance, single crystals of compound 5 suitable for X-ray analyses were isolated. Interestingly, the structure obtained (5a) contained one monodentate L2 ligand, two PPh3 ligands and a methyl group to complete a four coordinate geometry around the palladium atom (Fig. 1 ). Crystal data collection and structural refinement parameters are given in Table S1. The emperical composition of 5a thus differs from 5 as was established in elemental analyses. The monodentate coordination of L2 demonstrate the hemilabile nature of these ligands as was recently reported by Attandoh et al. [29]. Thus it is reasonable to deduce that the change in coordination occurred during crystallization process. The bond lengths of Pd(1)N(3) of 2.1290 (19) Å is similar to those observed in related Pd(II) complexes of 2.1300 (19) Å and 2.1289 (19) Å [38–39]. The average bond distance for PdP of 2.3157(8) Å compares favourably to the average bond length of 2.3248Å for other related palladium phosphine complexes [40–42]. Significant distortions from the ideal square planar geometry were evident in bond angles for N(2)Pd(01)P(003) of 94.19(5)° and C(1)Pd(01)P(004) of 87.54(7)° presumably due to steric demands of the two bulkier PPh3 groups. In the solid state structure of 5a, there occurs hydrogen bonding between the benzimidazole NH and fluorine atom of the adjacent BAr4 anion (Fig. 1). 3.2 Methoxycarbonylation reactions of olefins catalyzed by complexes 1–5. 3.2.1 Preliminary screening of palladium complexes 1–5 in methoxycarbonylation reactions Preliminary evaluation of complexes 1–5 in the methoxycarbonylation of 1-hexene were performed at 60bar of CO, 90°C and [1-hexene]:HCl:[Pd]=200:10:1 (Scheme 3 ). The major products were methyl heptanoate (linear product A) and methyl 2-methylhexanoate (branched product B). The identities and compositions of the products were determined by GC–MS (Figs. S4 and S5). 3.2.2 Effect of complex structure on methoxycarbonylation of 1-hexene The catalytic activities of complexes 1–5 in the methoxycarbonylation of 1-hexene were studied in order to investigate the effect of complex structure on catalytic performance. The effect of ligand motif was observed to influence the catalytic activity of the resultant catalysts. For example, complex 4 bearing electron donating OCH3 group on the phenyl ring was found to be the most active (Table 1 , entry 4), while the corresponding complex 5, containing electron withdrawing bromide substituent was the least active (Table 1, entry 5). This trend is consistent with OCH3 forming stable Pd(II) active species while the Br substituent is likely to produce unstable Pd(II) catalysts. Less stable systems tend to promote reduction of the catalytically active Pd(II) species to the less active Pd(I)/Pd(0) [43–46]. Another factor that affected the catalytic activity was the PdCl/Me bonds on the complex structure. For instance, complexes 1 and 2 bearing PdCl and PdMe bonds displayed percentage conversions of 52% and 80%, respectively, (Table 1, entries 1 and 2). We attributed this observation to the ease of CO insertion into PdMe bond, unlike in PdCl system which must activated by methanol solvent [45]. We also compared the behaviour of the neutral and the corresponding cationic Pd(II) complexes. While the activity of 2 (80%) and its corresponding cationic species 4 (86%) were comparable, the percentage conversion obtained for 3 (39%) was appreciably higher than that observed for its cationic analogue complex 5 (29%) (Table 1, entries 2–5). We postulate that the cancellation of enhanced solubility (expected to increase activity) and increased steric bulk (expected to limit substrate coordination thus reduced activity) due to the bulkier PPh3 groups in the cationic systems might explain the insignificant differences between these two systems. The nature of the complex structure did not significantly influence the regioselectivity of the esters produced. For example, the neutral and cationic complexes 2 and 4 afforded 40% and 37% of the branched esters, respectively (Table 1, entries 2 and 4). It was expected that the bulkier PPh3 groups in the cationic complexes may hinder isomerization of the coordinated substrates leading to the formation of more linear products. Thus the insignificant effect of the PPh3 group on product regioselectivity might point to a different mechanism, possibly dissociation of the PPh3 group prior to alkene coordination. 3.2.3 Effect of PPh3 on methoxycarbonylation reactions of 1-hexene The catalytic performances of complexes 4 and 5 in the absence and presence of PPh3 were performed in order to further probe the effect of triphenyl phosphine (PPh3) on the catalytic activities and selectivity of these systems. From the results, it was apparent that addition of PPh3 to the palladium complexes (Table 1, entries 6 and7) resulted in higher catalytic activities. For instance, using complex 4, percentage conversions of 86% and 37% were realized in the presence of 2 molar equivalent and absence of PPh3, respectively. From literature reports [47–48], it is believed that PPh3 group improves the stability of the active species by limiting decomposition to Pd(0) [11]. Indeed, extensive decomposition of the complexes to Pd(0) black was observed in reactions performed without PPh3. Regioselectivity of the ester products was also influenced by addition of PPh3 to the catalytic system. As an illustration, addition of PPh3 to the complex 5 resulted in a decrease of the branched ester from 68% to 40% (Table 1, entries 3 and 7). This trend could largely be attributed to steric hindrance from the bulkier PPh3 ligand thus limiting chain isomerization to form the sterically demanding branched esters [47]. In related experiments, Seayad et al. [49] and Del Río et al. [48] reported regioselectivities of 45–86% and 21–34% towards branched esters in the absence and presence of PPh3, respectively. 3.2.4 Effect of acid promoters on methoxycarbonylation reactions The nature of the acid promoter has been established to play a major role in Pd(II) catalyzed methoxycarbonylation of olefins [50–51]. We thus investigated the effect of various acid promoters; HCl, H2SO4, and p-TSOH on the catalytic performance of complex 4 using 1-hexene substrate. The results obtained clearly illustrate the importance of the acid promoters; while no catalytic activity was reported using p-TsOH, conversions of 42% and 86% were achieved using HCl and H2SO4, respectively, (Table 2 , entries 9–10). These results are not surprising and have been associated with the coordinating abilities of the respective acid promoters to stabilize the active Pd(II) species [52–54]. It is not clear how the nature of the acid promoter changed the regioslectivity towards the branched esters from 37% to 47% using HCl and H2SO4, respectively. 3.2.5 Effect of reaction conditions on methoxycarbonylation of 1-hexene The effect of reactions conditions such as carbon monoxide pressure, temperature, reaction time and substrate/catalyst ratio were also studied in order to optimize the catalytic conditions using complex 4. Changing the CO pressure from 50 and 60bar led to a substantial increase in percentage conversion from 50% and 86%, respectively, (Table 2, entries 11 and 12). This observation could be attributed to increased insertion of CO at high concentrations. However, there was no appreciable change in product regioselectivity with change in CO pressure. We did not observe any effect on the catalytic activity of 4 with change in reaction temperature as was evident in comparable conversions of 85% and 86% at 60°C and 90°C, respectively. The effect of catalyst concentration was also investigated by varying substrate/catalyst ratio from 100 to 400 at fixed substrate concentration (Table 2, entries 9, 13–14). Increasing the substrate/catalyst ratio from 100 to 400 led to a remarkable decrease in activity from 86% to 55% in accordance with the previous reports of Tooze and co-workers [55] and Vavasori et al. [56]. We noted that increasing substrate/catalyst ratio 100–400 (Table 2, entries 9, 13–14) also resulted in decreased regioselectivity towards the branched esters from 50% to 31%. This hints that at higher catalyst loadings, isomerization reactions were favoured. Lastly, the effect of time on catalytic activity and regioselectivity of the ester products was probed using catalyst 4. Maximum conversion of 99% was obtained within 36h, while only 49% was attained within 12h (Table 2, entries, 15 and 17). It is noteworthy to mention that increasing reaction time from 12h to 36h, resulted in significant shift to the branched esters from 28% to 55% (Fig. 2 ). This trend is consistent with increased chain isomerization of 1-hexene prior to methoxycarbonylation with time. 3.2.6 Effect of olefin substrate on methoxycarbonylation reactions using 4 Upon establishing the optimum reaction conditions for the methoxycarbonylation reactions, complex 4 was used in the methoxycarbonylation of a range of alkene substrates; styrene, 1-octene, 1-nonene and 1-decene (Fig. 3 ). It was clear from the results that the catalytic activity of 4 was significantly affected by the nature of the substrate. For example, changing from 1-hexene to 1-decene drastically decreased the percentage conversion from 86% to 10%. It is therefore apparent that increasing the chain length lowers the catalytic activity of 4 possibly due to increased steric hindrance or reduced reactivity of the higher olefins. More importantly, regioselectivity towards the branched/linear esters was also affected by the nature of the alkene substrate in which higher alkenes favoured the formation of branched esters. For instance, compositions of 37% and 67% of the branched esters were obtained for 1-hexene and 1-decene, respectively. This occurrence could be partly assigned to the higher number of possible isomers present in the higher alkenes compared to lower alkenes. The lower selectivity towards the branched isomer using styrene substrate (18%) compared to 1-hexene (37%) could be attributed to the bulkier phenyl groups in styrene which might favour the less sterically demanding linear isomer and/or limit chain isomerization to produce the branched isomers. 3.2.7 Proposed mechanism for palladium catalyzed methoxycarbonylation reactions Palladium catalysed methoxycarbonlylation of olefins have been proposed to occur via two possible mechanisms: hydride and carbomethoxy routes (Scheme 4 ) [57]. For complexes 1–5, both of these mechanisms are highly possible due to coordinative unsaturation of the palladium metal center resulting from possible loss of PPh3 group. At this stage, we are cannot unambiguously establish the preferred mechanistic pathway. In the carbomethoxy route (A), the cycle is initiated by the formation of a PdOMe bond aided by HCl acid. This is followed by migratory insertion of CO into the PdOMe to give an ester, prior to olefin substrate coordination. In the hydride cycle (B), the formation of a PdH bond occurs in the activation stage instead of a PdOMe bond. This is then followed by olefin coordination and subsequently CO coordination and migratory insertion to form a coordinated ketone. The product is ester product and generation of the PdH active species is achieved by methanolysis reaction. In both cases, the formation of linear or branched isomers are determined by the 1,2 or 2,1 olefin insertions. The role of the PPh3 group is mainly to stabilize the 14-electron species upon formation of the PdH or PdOMe active species. This was supported by enhanced stability of the catalysts when PPh3 was added to the catalyst system. 4 Conclusions In summary, this work has demonstrated the potential of (benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl) amine palladium complexes to catalyze methoxycarbonylation of alkenes to afford linear and branched esters with 100% chemoselectivity. Complex structure and alkene substrate significantly affected both the catalytic activity and product regioselectivity of the resultant catalysts. We are currently fine-tuning the catalyst structure in order to shift regioselectivity towards the more desirable branched esters. Supplementary information Supplementary Table S1 contains the data collection and structural refinement parameters of complex 5a. Figs. S1–S2 represent 31P NMR and mass spectra of complex 5, respectively. Fig. S3 represents the hydrogen bonding interactions in complex 5a. Figs. S4–S5 show GC-chromatograms and GC–MS spectra of the ester products, respectively. CCDC number 1056837 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for complex 5a. This data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. coredata.dc:description: Reactions of N-(1H-benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl)-2-methoxy aniline (L1) and N-(1H-benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl)-2-bromo aniline (L2) with either [PdCl2(COD)] or [PdClMe(COD)] afforded the neutral palladium complexes [PdCl2(L1)] (1), [PdClMe(L1)] (2) and [PdClMe(L2] (3), respectively. Treatment of 2 and 3 with one equivalent of PPh3 in the presence of NaBAr4 (Ar=3,5-(CF3)2C6H3) produced the corresponding cationic species, [PdMe(L1)]BAr4 (4) and [PdMe(L2)]BAr4 (5). All the palladium complexes formed active catalysts in the methoxycarbonylation of alkenes to produce linear and branched esters. The catalytic behaviour was dependent on the catalyst structure, presence of PPh3, acid promoter and alkene chain length.
coredata.dc:title: Palladium complexes of (benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl)amine ligands as catalysts for methoxycarbonylation of olefins
